column2: The guide teaches how to create a `Dockerfile` file describing a simple .NET Core service container.
The guide explains how to build, run, and verify the functionality of the .NET Core service.
The guide shows how to add Docker files to the .NET Core project using the Docker extension in VS Code.
The guide demonstrates how to add an environment variable to the service container image using the `ENV` instruction in the `Dockerfile`.
The guide instructs on how to test the .NET Core service container by running it and verifying it in the Docker Explorer.
By default, Docker assigns a randomly chosen host port to a port exposed by a container.
In the application, the exposed (container) port is 5000.
You can verify which host port is being used by the container by right-clicking the container in the Docker Explorer and choosing **Inspect**.

column1: Docker run options for specific port?
column2: You can use specific port on the host by changing the Docker run options used by `docker-run: debug` task.

column1: Customize Docker build and run tasks?
column2: You can customize your Docker build and run tasks by modifying the `.vscode/tasks.json` file.
